Study: A rapid review of evidence of infection of pets and livestock with human-associated coronavirus diseases, SARS, MERS, and COVID-19, and evidence of the fomite potential of pets and livestock
Excerpt: There is evidence from seeder models that cats and ferrets can become infected with SARSCoV-2 and this is detectable using PCR. There is evidence that cats in Wuhan, China have antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 which appears to have developed after the outbreak.

Study: A rapid review of evidence of infection of pets and livestock with human-associated coronavirus diseases, SARS, MERS, and COVID-19, and evidence of the fomite potential of pets and livestock
Excerpt: Dogs may become infected and produce antibodies, but there is no evidence that they develop clinical disease if exposed, or that they shed virus which may pose a risk to humans.

Study: An Overview of SARS‐CoV‐2 and Animal Infection
Excerpt: experimentally infected Egyptian fruit bats show no symptoms of disease, moreover, they do not infect other bats [14].

Study: An Overview of SARS‐CoV‐2 and Animal Infection
Excerpt: These results suggest that pangolin could be a potential intermediate host for SARS-CoV-2 [18].

Study: An Overview of SARS‐CoV‐2 and Animal Infection
Excerpt: ACE2 of turtle and snake loses its capability to bind to S protein of SARS-CoV-2, therefore these reptiles should not be considered as potential hosts for SARS-CoV-2

Study: An Overview of SARS‐CoV‐2 and Animal Infection
Excerpt: ACE2 of turtle and snake loses its capability to bind to S protein of SARS-CoV-2, therefore these reptiles should not be considered as potential hosts for SARS-CoV-2

Study: An Overview of SARS‐CoV‐2 and Animal Infection
Excerpt: SARS-CoV-2 infects cat populations in Wuhan during the COVID-19 outbreak based on detection of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies in those cats. Infection to those cats arise upon contact with COVID-19 patients or SARS-CoV-2 polluted environment [22]. In addition, SARS-CoV 2 has been detected in the feces and vomit of an infected pet cat with COVID-19 in Belgium indicating active replication of the virus [23].

Excerpt: pet dogs in Hong Kong and North Italy have been infected with SARSCoV-2

Study: COVID-19 and pets: When pandemic meets panic
Excerpt: In late March 2020, health officials in Belgium reported that a cat from Liège province had also tested positive for SARS-CoV-2. On March 31, officials in Hong Kong reported that a cat was being kept in quarantine after testing positive for SARS-CoV-2 via oral, nasal, and rectal swabs.

Study: COVID-19 and pets: When pandemic meets panic
Excerpt: Shortly after the Pomeranian in Hong Kong tested positive for SARS-CoV-2, in March 2020, a second dog in Hong Kong also tested positive for the virus.

Study: COVID-19 and pets: When pandemic meets panic
Excerpt: a female Malayan tiger at the Wildlife Conservation Society’s Bronx Zoo in New York City also tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 on April 5

Study: Absence of SARS-CoV-2 infection in cats and dogs in close contact with a cluster of COVID-19 patients in a veterinary campus
Excerpt: Our study points to undetectable interspecific transmission of the SARS-CoV-2 virus between COVID-19 patients and domestic dogs or cats under the natural exposure conditions.

Study: Absence of SARS-CoV-2 infection in cats and dogs in close contact with a cluster of COVID-19 patients in a veterinary campus
Excerpt: Our study points to undetectable interspecific transmission of the SARS-CoV-2 virus between COVID-19 patients and domestic dogs or cats under the natural exposure conditions.

Study: Infection and Rapid Transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in Ferrets
Excerpt: SARS-CoV-2 was found to efficiently infect ferrets.

Study: Can companion animals become infected with Covid-19?
Excerpt: On 31 March, a third case, this time in a cat, was reported in Hong Kong by the GHKSAR . The cat had tested positive to Covid-19 on RT-PCR from oral, nasal and faecal samples but did not show any clinical signs of disease. Positive viral SARS-CoV-2 genes were also recently found in vomit and faeces from a cat tested at the University of Liège in Belgium, but more information is needed before any conclusions can be made. The consensus remains at this time that there is no evidence that infected pets are a source of infection for people or other pets.

Study: Can companion animals become infected with Covid-19?
Excerpt: This latest report of seroconversion means the dog created antibodies against the virus, suggesting that the weak infection would have caused an immune response from the dog and further supports a true infection caused by human-to-animal transmission. As of 25 March the AFCD had conducted tests on 17 dogs and eight cats, of which only two dogs had tested positive. Both dogs later tested negative on RT-PCR, indicating they were free of infection. The consensus remains at this time that there is no evidence that infected pets are a source of infection for people or other pets.

Study: SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing serum antibodies in cats: a serological investigation
Excerpt: These results demonstrated that SARS-CoV-2 has infected cat populations in Wuhan, implying that this risk could also occur at other outbreak regions.

Study: Susceptibility of ferrets, cats, dogs, and different domestic animals to SARS-coronavirus-2
Excerpt: These results indicate that SARS-CoV-2 can replicate in the upper respiratory tract of ferrets for up to eight days, without causing severe disease or death.
Measure of Evidence: detection: qPCR, virus titration, ELISA, histology

Study: Susceptibility of ferrets, cats, dogs, and different domestic animals to SARS-coronavirus-3
Excerpt: These results indicate that SARS-CoV-2 can replicate efficiently in cats, with younger cats being more permissive and, perhaps more importantly, the virus can transmit between cats via respiratory droplets.
Measure of Evidence: detection: qPCR, virus titration, ELISA, histology

Study: Susceptibility of ferrets, cats, dogs, and different domestic animals to SARS-coronavirus-4
Excerpt: Two virus-inoculated dogs seroconverted; the other two virus-inoculated dogs and the two contact dogs were all seronegative for SARS-CoV-2 according to the ELISA (Table 1, fig S7). These results indicate that dogs have low susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2.
Measure of Evidence: detection: qPCR, virus titration, ELISA, histology

Study: Susceptibility of ferrets, cats, dogs, and different domestic animals to SARS-coronavirus-5
Excerpt: These results indicate that pigs, chickens, and ducks are not susceptible to SARS-CoV-2.
Measure of Evidence: detection: qPCR, virus titration, ELISA, histology

Study: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) Outbreak: Could Pigs Be Vectors for Human Infections?
Excerpt: So far there is no evidence that pigs can become infected with SARS‐CoV‐2 or are capable to amplify the virus.
